description: Ubuntu 22.04 LTS CIS Benchmark - Section 7.1 System File Permissions

controls.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/passwd are configured
controls.description: The /etc/passwd file contains user account information that is used by many system utilities and therefore must be readable for these utilities to operate.
controls.rationale: It is critical to ensure that the /etc/passwd file is protected from unauthorized write access. Although it is protected by default, the file permissions could be changed either inadvertently or through malicious actions.
controls.remediation: Run the following command to set permissions on /etc/passwd: chmod 644 /etc/passwd

controls.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/passwd- are configured
controls.description: The /etc/passwd- file contains backup user account information.
controls.rationale: It is critical to ensure that the /etc/passwd- file is protected from unauthorized access.
controls.remediation: Run the following command to set permissions on /etc/passwd-: chmod 644 /etc/passwd-

controls.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/group are configured
controls.description: The /etc/group file contains a list of all the valid groups defined in the system.
controls.rationale: The /etc/group file needs to be protected from unauthorized changes by non-privileged users, but needs to be readable as many command utilities use it to map a GID to the group name.
controls.remediation: Run the following command to set permissions on /etc/group: chmod 644 /etc/group

controls.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/group- are configured
controls.description: The /etc/group- file contains backup group account information.
controls.rationale: It is critical to ensure that the /etc/group- file is protected from unauthorized access.
controls.remediation: Run the following command to set permissions on /etc/group-: chmod 644 /etc/group-

controls.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/shadow are configured
controls.description: The /etc/shadow file is used to store the information about user accounts that is critical to the security of those accounts, such as the hashed password and other security information.
controls.rationale: If attackers can gain read access to the /etc/shadow file, they can easily run a password cracking program against the hashed password to break it.
controls.remediation: Run the following command to set permissions on /etc/shadow: chmod 640 /etc/shadow

controls.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/shadow- are configured
controls.description: The /etc/shadow- file contains backup user password information.
controls.rationale: It is critical to ensure that the /etc/shadow- file is protected from unauthorized access.
controls.remediation: Run the following command to set permissions on /etc/shadow-: chmod 640 /etc/shadow-

controls.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/gshadow are configured
controls.description: The /etc/gshadow file is used to store the information about groups that is critical to the security of those accounts, such as the hashed password and other security information.
controls.rationale: If attackers can gain read access to the /etc/gshadow file, they can easily run a password cracking program against the hashed password to break it.
controls.remediation: Run the following command to set permissions on /etc/gshadow: chmod 640 /etc/gshadow

controls.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/gshadow- are configured
controls.description: The /etc/gshadow- file contains backup group password information.
controls.rationale: It is critical to ensure that the /etc/gshadow- file is protected from unauthorized access.
controls.remediation: Run the following command to set permissions on /etc/gshadow-: chmod 640 /etc/gshadow-

controls.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/shells are configured
controls.description: The /etc/shells file contains the list of valid login shells for users on the system.
controls.rationale: Setting the permissions to read/write for root only prevents non-privileged users from modifying the file.
controls.remediation: Run the following command to set permissions on /etc/shells: chmod 644 /etc/shells

controls.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/security/opasswd are configured
controls.description: The /etc/security/opasswd file stores the users' old passwords and can be checked to ensure that users are not recycling recent passwords.
controls.rationale: The /etc/security/opasswd file contains user password history. Setting the permissions to read/write for root only prevents non-privileged users from accessing the file.
controls.remediation: Run the following command to set permissions on /etc/security/opasswd: chmod 600 /etc/security/opasswd

controls.title: Ensure world writable files and directories are secured
controls.description: Unix-based systems support variable settings to control access to files. World writable files are the least secure.
controls.rationale: Data in world-writable files can be read, modified, and potentially compromised by any user on the system.
controls.impact: Many of the commands for finding world writable files can take a long time to run as they traverse the entire file system looking for matches.
controls.remediation: Removing write access for the "other" category (chmod o-w <filename>) is advisable, but always first check what function the file serves before making the change.

controls.title: Ensure no files or directories without an owner and a group exist
controls.description: Sometimes when administrators delete users or groups from the system they neglect to remove all files owned by those users or groups.
controls.rationale: A new user who is assigned the deleted user's user ID or group ID may then end up "owning" these files, and thus have more access on the system than was intended.
controls.remediation: Locate files that are owned by users or groups not listed in the system configuration files, and reset the ownership of these files to some active user on the system as appropriate.
